data.source: Polling station–level election returns (2009 Afghan presidential election); Electoral Complaints Commission (ECC) 10% ballot box recount; declassified ISAF combat incident reports; National Risk and Vulnerability Assessment (NRVA) 2007; LandScan population data; GTOPO30 elevation; ACLED and WITS event datasets.
data.wave_or_subset: 2009 Afghanistan presidential election; violence measured around election days and over longer periods; adjacent-district violence considered.
data.notes: Only polling-station level results available; observer reports are biased/incomplete; last-digit forensic test may incur Type I/II errors; much manipulation appears local prior to national tally; Taliban violence aimed to disrupt the process rather than aid specific candidates.

method.description: The study applies a forensic last-digit (Beber–Scacco) test to polling-station returns to flag potential manipulation, validates these signals against an ECC-ordered 10% ballot box recount, and models how violence relates to detected fraud using regression analyses. Violence is measured from declassified ISAF combat incident reports and linked to districts, including both local and adjacent-district measures and both short- and long-term windows. Models test an inverted U-shaped relationship (linear and squared terms for violence) and differential spatial displacement of fraud benefiting the incumbent versus the challenger, controlling for geography, development, logistics, and demographics.
steps: Assemble polling station–level election returns from the 2009 Afghan presidential election.
Compute last-digit frequencies for vote counts by district (and candidate) and perform chi-square tests against a uniform distribution to generate district-level p-values indicating potential fraud.
Obtain ECC recount results (10% random sample of boxes) and construct recount-based fraud indicators/ratios by fraud category.
Validate the last-digit test by correlating significant last-digit flags with recount-based fraud measures.

Compile violence measures from declassified ISAF combat incident reports; georeference incidents to districts; compute violence per 1,000 population for election-day and longer-term windows; compute adjacent-district violence.
Assemble controls (e.g., NRVA 2007 economic development, distance from Kabul, elevation from GTOPO30, electrification, LandScan population, number of closed stations; optionally ACLED/WITS events).
Estimate regression models (logit/OLS) relating fraud indicators to violence, including linear and squared terms (testing for an inverted U-shaped relationship).
Estimate models separating fraud benefiting the incumbent vs. challenger, including adjacent-district violence to test spatial displacement.
Assess robustness across datasets, time windows, and specifications; interpret coefficients and significance patterns.
method.models: Chi-square goodness-of-fit tests for last-digit uniformity; logistic and OLS regressions with linear and squared violence terms; models including adjacent-district violence to test spatial displacement.
method.outcome_variable: Indicators of electoral fraud: (a) last-digit test significance/p-values at the district/candidate level; (b) recount-based fraud ratios/categories; (c) candidate-specific fraud measures for Karzai (incumbent) and Abdullah (challenger).
method.independent_variables: Violence per 1,000 population (local); squared term for violence; adjacent-district violence; long-term vs. election-period violence measures; number of closed polling stations; electrification; elevation; distance from Kabul; economic development (NRVA 2007); population (LandScan); conflict event metrics (ACLED/WITS).
method.control_variables: Distance from Kabul; elevation (GTOPO30); electrification; economic development (NRVA 2007); population (LandScan); number of closed stations; alternative conflict event datasets (ACLED/WITS).

results.summary: Fraud and violence exhibit an inverted U-shaped relationship: fraud increases with moderate violence but declines at high violence levels. Fraud benefiting the incumbent shows no spatial displacement with neighboring violence, whereas fraud benefiting the challenger increases with adjacent-district violence and decreases with local violence, consistent with differences in loyalty networks. The last-digit forensic test aligns with recount evidence, indicating that a substantial share of boxes in flagged districts was manipulated.
